newsitem.title: POLAND: GiroCredit buys 40 pct of IB Austria Polish unit.
newsitem.headline: GiroCredit buys 40 pct of IB Austria Polish unit.

text.p: Austria's GiroCredit AG took a 40-percent stake in the Polish unit of Investmentbank Austria AG, boosting the latter's capital to 22.5 million zlotys, the Polish unit's head said on Monday.

Jacek Krawczyk, President of IB Austria Securities SA, told a news briefing that the partnership and the capital increase would allow his firm to expand its activities in its efforts to offer a full range of investment banking services.
"The capital increase makes IB Austria Securities the strongest non-banking securities house in Poland in terms of capital," Krawczyk said.

He said that IB Austria Securities, which was commemorating the first anniversary of its operations, would soon launch commercial paper borrowing, having received a licence to offer short-term debt securities earlier this month.
Krawczyk also said that the brokerage would seek licences to offer portfolio management and recommendations in order to offer a full range of services.

He said that even though the house quickly established itself as a significant player on the secondary securities market with about a two-percent share of turnover, the primary market remained its main focus.
Krawczyk said that more than 90 percent of IB Austria's secondary-market business was generated by Polish institutional clients.
He said that because of this year's light menu of new issues, especially privatisation offerings, the country's mass privatisation programme was the main source of interesting projects.
"It's a paradox that a programme designed as a one-time hybrid is now the main source of interesting privatisation projects," Krawczyk said.
He said IB Austria Securities saw its greatest opportunities in mid-sized offerings.
